message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the patient has an acute thyroiditis, which is commonly caused by viral infection. Histologic examination would most likely reveal follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate. This is characteristic of acute thyroiditis, whereas the other options are characteristic of other thyroid conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient’s history and examination findings, this is likely a thyroglossal duct cyst. The cyst arises from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which is a structure that connects the thyroid gland to the base of the tongue during embryonic development. It is lined by epithelial cells that resemble thyroid follicular cells and can become infected, resulting in tenderness and warmth. Histologic examination of the lesion would likely reveal follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate, consistent with a thyroglossal duct cyst. None of the other options are associated with this type of lesion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and presentation of the lump in the neck, along with the recent illness, suggest the most likely diagnosis of acute thyroiditis. Acute thyroiditis is often caused by a bacterial infection and can present with a tender, warm, and enlarged thyroid gland. Histologic examination would reveal follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate, consistent with the inflammatory nature of the condition. Options B, C, and D are not consistent with the presentation and location of the lump in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a neck mass, warm to palpation and tender, suggests acute thyroiditis, which is inflammation of the thyroid gland. Histologic examination of acute thyroiditis would show follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate. The other options are not associated with acute thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a thyroid abscess, which is often caused by a bacterial infection in the thyroid gland. Histologic examination would most likely reveal follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate, as this is consistent with an abscess. The other options are not consistent with a thyroid abscess.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely diagnosis is a thyroglossal duct cyst and the clinical presentation suggests infection. Therefore, histologic examination would most likely reveal follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate, which is consistent with a thyroid abscess. Answers B, C, and D would be more consistent with other types of neck masses, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma (B), Graves' disease (C), and a dermoid cyst (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a small, warm, tender, and movable neck mass suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst, which can develop after a respiratory tract infection. Histological examination would show follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate, which is typical for a thyroglossal duct cyst. All other options are not related to a thyroglossal duct cyst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination suggest that the child has a thyroglossal duct cyst, which can occur following respiratory infection. The mass is warm and tender to palpation, and moving superiorly when the patient drinks water due to the proximity to the hyoid bone. Histologic examination of a thyroglossal duct cyst would reveal follicular cells surrounding colloid and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate, as in option (A). Option (B) describes papillary thyroid carcinoma, which would be unlikely in a child. Option (C) describes goiter, which would be diffuse rather than a discrete mass. Option (D) describes a skin lesion such as a pilomatrixoma, which would be unlikely at this location.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass moving superiorly when the patient drinks water suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst. The characteristic histologic finding of these cysts is follicular cells surrounding colloid, and admixed with a neutrophilic infiltrate, as seen in option (A). Option (B) describes papillary thyroid carcinoma, option (C) describes multinodular goiter, and option (D) describes a dermoid cyst, none of which fit the patient's history and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s recent illness and the physical examination suggest the diagnosis of acute thyroiditis, specifically subacute thyroiditis. The mass is tender to palpation and moves with swallowing, which is consistent with subacute thyroiditis. Histologic examination would show follicular cells surrounding colloid, indicating thyroid tissue. The infiltration of neutrophils further supports the diagnosis of subacute thyroiditis.
